H. A. Lorentz

Dates

July 18, 1852 – February 4, 1928

Authorized Form of Name

Lorentz, H. A. (Hendrik Antoon), 1853-1928

Additional Forms of Names

Lorentz, Hendrik (A.), 1853-1928

Biography

Abstract

Hendrik Antoon Lorentz won the Nobel Prize in Physics "in recognition of the extraordinary service they rendered by their researches into the influence of magnetism upon radiation phenomena". His work in atomic physics, electromagnetism, and hydraulic engineering are still considered to be of great value to the physics field. Lorentz also served as an advocate for the sciences and put in motion the steps which led to the creation of the T.N.O., the Netherlands Organization for Applied Scientific Research.

July 18, 1853Birth, Arnhem (Netherlands).

1871Obtained BSc in mathematics and physics, Leiden University (Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden), Leiden (Netherlands).

1872Became a night school teacher, Arnhem (Netherlands).

1875Obtained Ph.D, Leiden University (Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden), Leiden (Netherlands).

1878Professor of Mathematical Physics (1875) and Chair of Theoretical Physics (1878), Leiden University (Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden), Leiden (Netherlands).

1878Published essay on what is now known as the Lorenz-Lorentz formula.

1898Appointed Honorary Member, London Mathematical Society.

1902Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics alongisde P. Zeeman "in recognition of the extraordinary service they rendered by their researches into the influence of magnetism upon radiation phenomena".

1904Famed work on FitzGerald-Lorentz contraction, known as Lorentz transformations.

1905Gained membership, Royal Society.

1908Speaker, International Congress.

1908Awarded Rumford Medal, Royal Society.

1911Chairman, Solvay Conference.

1912Secretary, Dutch Society of Sciences (Hollandsche Maatschappij der Wetenschappen).

1912Curator to Teylers Physical Cabinet, Teylers Museum.

1918Awarded Copley Medal, Royal Society.

1920Fellow, Royal Society of Edinburgh.

1923 – 1925Member (1923) and President (1925), International Committee of Intellectual Cooperation, League of Nations.

1926Presented a series of lectures on quantum mechanics, Cornell University, Ithaca (N.Y.).

February 4, 1928Death, Haarlem (Netherlands).
